docs.abstract: The People’s Liberation Army said U.S. indictments accusing four of its members of stealing information amounted to “legal bullying.”
docs.snippet: The People’s Liberation Army said U.S. indictments accusing four of its members of stealing information amounted to “legal bullying.”
docs.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China’s military on Thursday denied accusations that it hacked Equifax, one of the largest credit reporting companies in the United States.

headline.main: With Harsh Words, China’s Military Denies It Hacked Equifax
headline.print_headline: China’s Military Harshly Denies Accusations It Hacked Equifax

docs.abstract: A start-up called Truework aims to give workers more control when lenders contact their employers for employment and salary verification.
docs.snippet: A start-up called Truework aims to give workers more control when lenders contact their employers for employment and salary verification.
docs.lead_paragraph: A start-up is taking on Equifax’s employee verification service, and it now has a bit of a war chest too.

headline.main: A New Challenger to Equifax’s Employee Verification Service
headline.print_headline: Start-Up Challenges Equifax On Verifying Employment

docs.abstract: Regulators charged a second former worker, accusing him of buying stock options before the breach of 140 million consumers’ data became public.
docs.snippet: Regulators charged a second former worker, accusing him of buying stock options before the breach of 140 million consumers’ data became public.
docs.lead_paragraph: Regulators charged a second former Equifax employee with insider trading, accusing him on Thursday of placing a financial bet that the stock would decline after learning about the company’s huge data breach but before it was publicly disclosed.

headline.main: Another Equifax Employee Faces Charge of Insider Trading After Big Breach
headline.print_headline: Equifax Worker Charged With Insider Stock Trade

docs.abstract: A ruling could help determine whether companies will get away with abusing our data.
docs.snippet: A ruling could help determine whether companies will get away with abusing our data.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 19, District Judge Thomas Thrash of Atlanta will hold a final approval hearing for the Equifax 2017 data breach settlement. There’s a lot at stake. If the settlement is approved, the $31 million pool earmarked for claims will be paid out to some victims. Others will get free credit monitoring (because the cash reward set aside for victims was so small, if all 147 million people affected by the breach filed a claim, everyone would get just 21 cents).

headline.main: One Man Can Bring Equifax to Justice (and Get You Your Money)

docs.abstract: It’s difficult to determine how and where companies like Facebook went wrong, which makes regulation challenging.
docs.snippet: It’s difficult to determine how and where companies like Facebook went wrong, which makes regulation challenging.
docs.lead_paragraph: What happens to the companies that allow our personal data to be stolen? In most cases, nothing. Sometimes there is a short-lived flurry of bad publicity, a brief dip in stock prices, a class-action lawsuit or a Federal Trade Commission investigation that leads to a token settlement or fine. Facebook is unlikely to face any serious, long-term consequences as a result of a security breach it announced last month, which exposed the account data of 50 million users.

headline.main: Why It’s So Hard to Punish Companies for Data Breaches
headline.print_headline: A Penalty Too Low For Security Breaches

docs.abstract: FICO is tweaking its all-important formula. Scores will rise for about 40 million people and drop for another 40 million.
docs.snippet: FICO is tweaking its all-important formula. Scores will rise for about 40 million people and drop for another 40 million.
docs.lead_paragraph: Your credit score — that all-important passport within the financial world — may be about to change. And it won’t necessarily be because of anything you did or didn’t do.

headline.main: Your Credit Score May Soon Change. Here’s Why.
headline.print_headline: FICO Tweak May Change Credit Scores

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)

docs.abstract: Companies like Equifax threaten our personal privacy and our national security.
docs.snippet: Companies like Equifax threaten our personal privacy and our national security.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Monday, the Justice Department announced that it was charging four members of China’s People’s Liberation Army with the 2017 Equifax breach that resulted in the theft of personal data of about 145 million Americans.

headline.main: Chinese Hacking Is Alarming. So Are Data Brokers.
headline.print_headline: Data Brokers Are Like Hackers, but Legal

docs.abstract: A year after the Equifax security breach, most people have not frozen their credit records. Consumer advocates recommend freezes to foil identity theft.
docs.snippet: A year after the Equifax security breach, most people have not frozen their credit records. Consumer advocates recommend freezes to foil identity theft.
docs.lead_paragraph: Consumers will soon be able to freeze their credit files without charge. So if you have not yet frozen your files — a recommended step to foil identity theft — now is a good time to take action, consumer advocates say.

headline.main: Freezing Credit Will Now Be Free. Here’s Why You Should Go for It.
headline.print_headline: New Law Makes Freezing Credit Files Free

docs.abstract: Credit experts often recommend a freeze as a way to protect personal information from fraud and identity theft.
docs.snippet: Credit experts often recommend a freeze as a way to protect personal information from fraud and identity theft.
docs.lead_paragraph: Americans will soon have the right to freeze their credit files free of charge.

headline.main: New Law Will Let Consumers ‘Freeze’ Credit Files Without Charge
headline.print_headline: New Law Will Let Consumers Freeze Credit Files Without Charge

docs.abstract: A new law requiring credit bureaus to offer you free freezes applies to children, too. It’s easier than you’d expect, but you may still have questions. Here are some answers.
docs.snippet: A new law requiring credit bureaus to offer you free freezes applies to children, too. It’s easier than you’d expect, but you may still have questions. Here are some answers.
docs.lead_paragraph: You can now freeze your child’s credit files for free — and it isn’t as difficult as even the most cynical among you might expect it to be.

headline.main: You Should Freeze Your Child’s Credit. It’s Not Hard. Here’s How.
headline.print_headline: Why Parents Should Freeze Child’s Credit
